channel.title: Partitions
channel.description: So basically I want to delete Windows 7 from my file system. But on every tutorial they say I need to delete the partition. So my question is, dafuq is a partition? And also, when I delete my C partition, does it delete my whole C drive or something?

item.title: Partitions
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

The only way you’re going to be able to do that is boot into a LiveCD of some sort (linux, Hiren’s, Windows Rescue CD, etc) Then just open up a partition manager, delete the partition, save changes, reboot.

Just be sure that you have some method of installing another OS, or else you’ll have a nice paperweight.

Read full topic

item.title: Partitions
item.dc:creator: @classic mopmans little slave
item.description:
@classic wrote:

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:9, topic:436442”][quote author=Classic_ link=topic=539155.msg3952226#msg3952226 date=1332380043]

How would I do that budd

Well, for example when I had Windows XP Pro for example, and downloaded a cracked version of Windows 7 Ultimate, I simply clicked on the install button, and it went from there, from there it would save a folder called ‘Windows.Old’ and it would save all my Windows XP information in that folder until I wanted to clean it.

do you have any idea of what your saying. he is talking about ubuntu.
First of all, install Ubuntu first as a partion, a partion is a part of the drive that you are going to separate for your ubuntu, then what you do is you is go through ubuntu and into the other partion, and delete it. Though I don’t see why you should not keep it, W7 is useful at times.
[/quote]
Comparing dummie.[/quote]
no need to hurt mah feelings D:

Read full topic

Well, for example when I had Windows XP Pro for example, and downloaded a cracked version of Windows 7 Ultimate, I simply clicked on the install button, and it went from there, from there it would save a folder called ‘Windows.Old’ and it would save all my Windows XP information in that folder until I wanted to clean it.
[/quote]
do you have any idea of what your saying. he is talking about ubuntu.
First of all, install Ubuntu first as a partion, a partion is a part of the drive that you are going to separate for your ubuntu, then what you do is you is go through ubuntu and into the other partion, and delete it. Though I don’t see why you should not keep it, W7 is useful at times.[/quote]

item.title: Partitions
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:4, topic:436442”][quote author=Native^ link=topic=539155.msg3945536#msg3945536 date=1331825523]
Yes I got that part. Got another question. If I delete all my partitions and install Ubuntu again, will that just work?
[/quote]
Like I said; just over-write it mate, no need to go through all that trouble.[/quote]
no.

delete the partitions you won’t be using - you need to anyway if you wish to create a layout for your linux install. a few clicks in a UI or a few commands in a CLI isn’t that much trouble.

[quote=“Classic_, post:7, topic:436442”][quote author=Ix Soulcist xI link=topic=539155.msg3945559#msg3945559 date=1331827682]

How would I do that budd

Well, for example when I had Windows XP Pro for example, and downloaded a cracked version of Windows 7 Ultimate, I simply clicked on the install button, and it went from there, from there it would save a folder called ‘Windows.Old’ and it would save all my Windows XP information in that folder until I wanted to clean it.
[/quote]
do you have any idea of what your saying. he is talking about ubuntu.
First of all, install Ubuntu first as a partion, a partion is a part of the drive that you are going to separate for your ubuntu, then what you do is you is go through ubuntu and into the other partion, and delete it. Though I don’t see why you should not keep it, W7 is useful at times.[/quote]
protip: minimally linux needs two partitions to operate.
protip2: there’s a partition phase of the install that occurs right before copying the system files for linux, soooo you can just do it then.

Read full topic

item.title: Partitions
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

You could over-write the partition with another OS, but I’m not too sure on how to delete the partition manually as far as waiting on installing another OS, but indeed could over-write it.
